steps.title: The ouroboros is a symbol showing a snake eating its own tail.
steps.content: The ouroboros is a symbol showing a snake eating its own tail. The word “ouroboros” derives from Ancient Greek words for “devouring its tail.” Oὐρά (oura) means 'tail' and -βορός (-boros) means '-eating'. [1] X Research source The snake – or sometimes a dragon – is most often curled into a circle, but is sometimes shown in a figure 8, like an infinity symbol .

steps.title: Ouroboros generally symbolizes the cycle of death and rebirth.
steps.content: Ouroboros generally symbolizes the cycle of death and rebirth. However, others have interpreted it as symbolizing duality, unity, eternity, completion, and regeneration. [2] X Research source Academics are not certain what it originally symbolized because no explanations have yet been discovered. [3] X Research source The ouroboros has also been associated with the nature of time or the natural world.

steps.title: One of the oldest-known ouroboroses was found in King Tut’s tomb.
steps.content: One of the oldest-known ouroboroses was found in King Tut’s tomb. The symbol was a part of The Enigmatic Book of the Netherworld , which is a funerary text that appears on one of King Tutankhamun’s gilded burial shrines. The ouroboros appears around the head and feet of what is thought to be Ra-Osiris. [4] X Research source Some believe the ouroboros symbolized Ra, the Egyptian sun god, and his daily journey across the sky. Other theories connect the ouroboros to the sky goddess Nut. It also represented the chaos that surrounds the orderly world. [5] X Research source An ouroboros that predates the Egyptian symbol has been found on pottery created by the Neolithic Yangshao People who lived in what is now eastern China along the Yellow River. It’s believed to have symbolized the idea of unity. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Many mythologies and religions reference a serpent biting its tail.
steps.content: Many mythologies and religions reference a serpent biting its tail. Several of these serpents are believed to surround the world and divide it from what lies beyond. The symbol has been found in temples, artifacts, and artworks from China, Greece, Scandinavia, India, and the Amazon basin. [7] X Research source Greece Plato interpreted the ouroboros as symbolizing self reliance. Some historians connect it to the myth of Sisyphus, doomed to roll a boulder up a hill only to have it roll back down again as soon as he reaches the top. [8] X Research source Rome In ancient Rome, the ouroboros was associated with the god Saturn, who connected December to January to begin the year anew. It symbolized infinity. [9] X Research source Scandinavia Jörmungandr (also known as the Midgard Serpent or the World Snake) was an immense snake who was said to encircle the world by holding his tail in his mouth. During Ragnarök, he would release his tail to join the battle against the gods that would bring the end of the world. It symbolised transformation and rejuvenation. [10] X Research source South America Indigenous people in the South American lowlands believe that the world is a disc shape with a snake circling it. The snake is sometimes depicted as biting its tail. It symbolizes the cycles of death and rebirth. [11] X Research source China Some historians believe the Chinese Yin-Yang was transformed into the ouroboros when scholars in ancient Alexandria were exposed to Chinese alchemy. The Chinese believed that Yin-Yang was dual-natured and responsible for creation. [12] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source India In one Hindu myth, the world is supported on the backs of 4 elephants that stand on the back of a turtle. [13] X Research source In some depictions, the turtle stands on the back of a snake biting its own tail. The idea of a snake biting its own tail is also used in the Vedic text Aitareya Brahmana and the Yoga-kundalini Upanishad . It represents infinity or eternity. Iberia Uma pescadinha de rabo na boca (trans. "tail-in mouth little hake") and La pescadilla que se muerde la cola (trans. "the hake that bites its tail") are expressions in Portuguese and Spanish that refer to circular reasoning and being caught in a vicious circle. [14] X Research source North America In the United States, there are widespread tales about a large snake that bites its own tail and then rolls around like a hoop or wheel. The hoop snake has a stinger in its tail that it can use to poison a predator. There doesn’t appear to be a specific interpretation for these creatures. [15] X Research source

steps.title: The Gnostics believed the ouroboros symbolized unity with the divine.
steps.content: The Gnostics believed the ouroboros symbolized unity with the divine. Early Christian and Jewish philosophers or Gnostics believed humans have a direct relationship with God. The ouroboros symbolized that unity with the divine, with the head being God and the tail being humans. [16] X Research source The Gnostics also depicted Leviathan from the Christian Bible as an ouroboros and can symbolize the pursuit of enlightenment.

steps.title: In alchemy, the ouroboros symbolized transformation.
steps.content: In alchemy, the ouroboros symbolized transformation. Alchemy was an ancient forerunner of Chemistry. The main goal of most alchemists was to discover the secret of turning base metals into gold and discover a universal elixir for everlasting life. [17] X Research source The ancient alchemist Cleopatra the Alchemist used the ouroboros in her scroll Cleopatra's Chrysopoeia , which some believe holds the secret to transmuting base metals into gold. [18] X Research source Psychiatrist Carl Jung defined the alchemical ouroboros as infinity or wholeness. [19] X Research source

steps.title: The ouroboros has been used in several scientific disciplines.
steps.content: The ouroboros has been used in several scientific disciplines. This symbol has been used to inspire scientists and illustrate scientific ideas in the modern-day much as it has throughout history. German chemist August Kekule von Stradonitz dreamed of an ouroboros, which helped him understand the chemical structure of benzene. He used this knowledge to establish the foundation for structural theory in organic chemistry. [20] X Research source Astrophysicist Martin Rees used it to illustrate the interconnectedness between the inner space of atoms and the outer space of the universe. [21] X Research source The ouroboros is a metaphor for self-reference in cybernetics. [22] X Research source

steps.title: The ouroboros has been a common symbol in pop culture.
steps.content: The ouroboros has been a common symbol in pop culture. The symbol has captured the imagination of artists, writers, and marketers to symbolize cycles and interconnections between the past and the present or alternate worlds. steps.title: Ouroboros tattoos symbolize renewal and rebirth.
steps.content: Ouroboros tattoos symbolize renewal and rebirth. People get tattoos for many reasons, including personal expression and taking symbolic control of their image and body. [23] X Research source As a tattoo, the ouroboros can be a powerful symbol of renewal, much like a phoenix that emerges from the ashes. It may also symbolize eternity or infinity, especially if the ouroboros is twisted in a figure-8. While many people get an ouroboros tattoo for its symbolic meaning, some may get it just because they think it looks cool.

steps.title: Snakes occasionally bite their own bodies when in pain.
steps.content: Snakes occasionally bite their own bodies when in pain. There have been a few instances where snakes in captivity have bitten their own tails. When snakes are in a great deal of pain, they can blindly strike their own bodies. [24] X Research source However, this is not a common behavior for snakes in the wild.

steps.title: An African Armadillo-Girdled Lizard bites its own tail for protection.
steps.content: An African Armadillo-Girdled Lizard bites its own tail for protection. Researchers gave this lizard the scientific name Ouroborus cataphractus because it resembles an ouroboros when it rolls itself into a ball and bites its own tail for protection. [25] X Research source
